occurrences.line_text: Had spred her purple robe through deawy aire,
Where grew two goodly trees, that faire did spred
High aboue all a cloth of State was spred,
With greedie pawes, and ouer all did spred
Which flying fame throughout the world had spred,
Clymbe to her charet, all with flowers spred;
And spred his glorie through all countries wide.
The dead corse of an armed knight was spred,
Through which the fragrant Eglantine did spred
Her cunning web, and spred her subtile net,
And spred his empire to the vtmost shore,
Vpon the waues to spred her trembling light,
When suddeinly a grosse fog ouer spred
And ouer all, of purest gold was spred,
And whilst he slept, she ouer him would spred
Did spred it selfe, and venime close inspire.
Ne tastest Princes pleasures, ne doest spred
Which through the earth haue spred their liuing prayse,
And comming forth, shall spred his banner braue
Speed thee to spred abroad thy beames bright?
Yet all was forg'd and spred with golden foyle,
With golden foyle doth finely ouer spred
And with their braunches spred all Britany,
To all about, and all her shoulders spred
Their bodies to his beasts for prouender did spred.
All ouer her a cloth of state was spred,
Did spred abroad, and throw in th'open wynd.
Did spred it selfe, to serue to all delight,
Mantled with greene, it selfe did spredden wyde,
They him disarm'd, and spredding on the ground
And spredding ouer all the flore alone,
And both behind vpheld her spredding traine;
Couered with mossie shrubs, which spredding brode
Spredding pauilions for the birds to bowre,
When her discolourd bow she spreds through heauens hight.
And spreds it selfe through all ciuilitie:
And when thou spredst thy mantle forth on hie,
And other where the snowy substaunce sprent
That all the ground with purple bloud was sprent,
Had made a Lady of that other Spright,
Hauing yrockt a sleepe his irkesome spright,
With that misformed spright he backe returnd againe.
That feigning dreame, and that faire-forged Spright
And that false other Spright, on whom he spred
Or guilefull spright wandring in empty aire,
Let not his loue, let not his restlesse spright
In slombring swownd nigh voyd of vitall spright,
For wondrous great griefe groneth in my spright,
His chearefull words reuiu'd her chearelesse spright,
Ne diuelish thoughts dismay thy constant spright.
And when she list poure out her larger spright,
Which knowne, and all that noyd his heauie spright
In that sad house of Penaunce, where his spright
Yet wondrous quick and persant was his spright,
Till from her bands the spright assoiled is,
Ah puissaunt Lords, what cursed euill Spright,
To which his flowing toung, and troublous spright
But when the franticke fit inflamd his spright,
That quickned the dull spright with musicall comfort.
And groneth out his vtmost grudging spright,
In his owne flesh, and make way to the liuing spright.
And low abase the high heroicke spright,
The charge thereof vnto a couetous Spright
But all so soone as his enfeebled spright
As if some pensiue thought co[n]straind her gentle spright.
To be no earthly wight, but either Spright,
That made his spright to grone full piteous:
Yet nathemore forth fled his groning spright,
Flesh without bloud, a person without spright,
And through his humid eyes did sucke his spright,
Faire Malecasta, whose engrieued spright
Did chaunce to still into her wearie spright,
Her chearefull words much cheard the feeble spright
By false illusion of a guilefull Spright,
Or euill spright, that in her doth such torment breed.
Both coosen passions of distroubled spright,
Was earst impressed in her gentle spright:
And thought her to adore with humble spright;
He neare was touched in his noble spright,
Of life, she put a Spright to rule the carkasse dead.
A wicked Spright yfraught with fawning guile,
To gin awake, and stirre his frozen spright:
Did him attonce oppresse, and vex his caytiue spright.
All desperate of his fore-damned spright,
And nothing left, but like an aery Spright,
She dolefull Lady, like a dreary Spright,
Yet freshly bleeding forth her fainting spright,
But most faire Amoret, whose gentle spright
And in sweete rauishment pourd out her spright:
Yet now he was surpriz'd: for that false spright,
Through secret feeling of his generous spright,
As all men do, that lose the liuing spright:
The other breathing now another spright,
But Blandamour full of vainglorious spright,
That sudden newes had made into his spright;
And hard to finde, that heat of youthfull spright
To see his foe breath out his spright in vaine:
Was slaine: but that which is th'immortall spright
Being fast fixed in her wounded spright,
But with thy bloud thou shalt appease the spright
There did appeare vnto her heauenly spright
Like one adawed with some dreadfull spright.
Beheld, it much appald her troubled spright:
And with dull countenance, and with doleful spright,
It strength to me supplies, & chears my dulled spright.
In whom it seemes, that gentlenesse of spright
Of all this day on ground, that breathen liuing spright.
That he nould let him breath nor gather spright,
Doe it disclose, to ease your grieued spright:
So that he now has almost spent his spright.
Ne all the skill, which that immortall spright
And al the passio[n]s heale, which wou[n]d the weaker spright.
In cancred malice and reuengefull spright.
And being fresh and full of youthly spright,
And standing long astonished in spright,
Does charme her louers, and the feeble sprightes
Legions of Sprights, the which like little flyes
As one aghast with feends or damned sprights,
And damned sprights sent forth to make ill men aghast.
Plonged continually of cruell Sprights,
Where companing with feends and filthy Sprights,
When so he counseld with his sprights enco[m]past round.
Which thousand sprights with long enduring paines
Vnto these Sprights, to bring to perfect end.
Where she was wont her Sprights to entertaine
By errant Sprights, but from all men conceald:
Of wicked Sprights did fall from happy blis;
Now singing sweetly, to surprise her sprights,
Out of the dwellings of the damned sprights,
Therewith their dulled sprights they edgd anew,
Our wearie yokes, to gather fresher sprights,
Then that sweet verse, with Nectar sprinckeled,
Then gan they sprinckle all the posts with wine,
An holy water Sprinckle, dipt in deowe,
Sprinckle her heart, and haughtie courage soften,
And holy water thereon sprinckled wide;
And all his armour sprinckled was with bloud,
With yron toungs, and sprinckled oft the same
And sprinckled frost vpon his deawy beard:
With which she sprinckled fauours manifold,
That seem'd like siluer, sprinckled here and theare
And sprinckled with such sweet variety,
With sprincled pearle, and gold full richly drest,
But when his later spring gins to auale,
To be the chastest flowre, that ay did spring
Leaping like wanton kids in pleasant Spring.
Of what loines and what lignage I did spring:
Whom well she knew to spring from heauenly race,
Their welheads spring, and are with moisture dewd;
No tree, whose braunches did not brauely spring;
They spring, they bud, they blossome fresh and faire,
The fields did laugh, the flowres did freshly spring,
Of whom all Faeryes spring, and fetch their lignage right.
Did now but freshly spring, and silken blossomes beare.
Whence spring all noble deeds and neuer dying fame:
Shall spring, out of the auncient Troian blood,
From where the day out of the sea doth spring,
There is continuall spring, and haruest there
The glory of the later world to spring,
He wooed her, till day spring he espyde;
The spring breake forth out of his lusty bowres,
As a new spring; and likewise on her hed
Began to spring which shortly grew full great,
So from the Ocean all riuers spring,
The seede of all this euill first doth spring,
There came two Springals of full tender yeares,
which from them springen shall.
Adowne, as if their springes of life were spent;
Spring-headed Hydraes, and sea-shouldring Whales,
And you fresh bud of vertue springing fast,
Of auncient time there was a springing well,
Cleare the deawy ayre with springing light,
The sparks soone quench, the springing seed outweed,
In springing flowre the image of thy day;
Vnwares had borne two babes, as faire as springing day.
That in the Gardin of Adonis springs,
Sweet springs, in which a thousand Nymphs did play;
Long Rhodanus, whose sourse springs from the skie;
Bursting forth teares, like springs out of a banke,
For well I wote, thou springst from ancient race
And euer with sweet Nectar she did sprinkle him.
She lightly sprinkled on his weaker parts;
With pearly dew sprinkling the morning grasse:
By them the Sprite doth passe in quietly,
The Sprite then gan more boldly him to wake,
Nor guilefull sprite, to thee these wordes doth speake,
And rauished with rare impression in his sprite.
But in braue sprite it kindles goodly fire,
And gentle sprite deforme with rude rusticity.
Was much empassiond in her gentle sprite,
That at the last his wearie sprite opprest
That the faint sprite he did reuoke againe,
He that the stubborne Sprites can wisely tame,
Whose blessed sprites from vnderneath the stone
Some litle life his feeble sprites emong;
From which I sprong, from me are hidden yit.
And thou faire ymp, sprong out from English race,
And freely sprong out of the fruitfull ground,
Here also sprong that goodly golden fruit,
But whence they sprong, or how they were begot,
Whiles the salt brine out of the billowes sprong.
Rashly out of their rouzed couches sprong,
Or whence it sprong, I cannot read aright:
To Elfes, but sprong of seed terrestriall,
Well worthy stock, from which the branches sprong,
With heauenly seed, whereof wise Pï¿½on sprong)
So sprong these twinnes in wombe of Chrysogone,
For noble Britons sprong from Troians bold,
In Princes Court doe hap to sprout againe,
Sprung of the auncient stocke of Princes straine,
Eftsoones out sprung two more of equall mould;
Which of them sprung by lineall descent:
He spued vp his gorge, that all did him deteast.
He does backebite, and spightfull poison spues
The fierce Spumador trode them downe like docks,
The fierce Spumador borne of heauenly seed:
By griesly Lachesis was spun with paine,
When with the maistring spur he did him roughly stire.
And makes her feare a spur to hast her flight:
When his hot ryder spurd his chauffed side;
But all spurd after fast, as they mote fly,
So bent his speare, and spurnd his horse with yron heele.
His poinant speare, and sharpely gan to spurne
Forth spurred fast: adowne his coursers side
With that he put his spurres vnto his steed,
But putting spurres vnto her fiery beast,
Spurring so hote with rage dispiteous,
Gay steed with spurs did pricke, the good Sir Mortdant was.
And Atin aie him pricks with spurs of shame & wrong.
Soone as the royall virgin he did spy,
And looked all about, if she might spy
Whom when the damned feend so fresh did spy,
Then turning to the Palmer, he gan spy
Which when those wicked Hags from farre did spy,
At last farre off they many Islands spy,
Scarse had he said, when hard at hand they spy
Whereas the hungry Spaniels she does spy,
Suspect her truth, and keepe continuall spy
And his owne armes when glittering he did spy,
When he in place his dearest loue did spy;
Soone as the knight she there by her did spy,
Which when the Damzell neare at hand did spy,
Yet when as fit aduantage he did spy,
Whereto when as my presence he did spy
He chaunst far off an armed Knight to spy,
To spy where he may some aduauntage get;
He chaunst to spy a sort of shepheard groomes,
He chaunst one comming towards him to spy,
Lapped in flowres and pretious spycery,
A damzell spyde slow footing her before,
Vnto an hill; from whence when she him spyde,
That of no enuious eyes he mote be spyde:
Which when the Gyaunt spyde with staring eye,
To haue deuourd, so soone as day he spyde,
Thus as he spake, lo far away they spyde
Till that at last, when he aduantage spyde,
That when the Paynim spyde the streaming blood,
A stately Castle farre away she spyde,
Thus as she her recomforted, she spyde,
When walking through the Gardin, them she spyde,
But forward gallopt fast; which when he spyde,
Late forth she sent, she backe returning spyde,
They spyde a knight faire pricking on the plaine,
She slept, yet twixt her eyelids closely spyde,
At last she spyde at that roomes vpper end,
Lo where they spyde with speedie whirling pace,
A Knight soft ryding towards them they spyde,
I spyde, where at the Idoles feet apart
Like as a Puttocke hauing spyde in sight
But as he nigher drew, three knights he spyde,
To follow his first quest, when as he spyde
He sought him farre and neare, yet him no where he spyde.
The gentle Prince not farre away they spyde,
Whereat the Prince awaking, when he spyde
He spyde, lamenting her vnluckie strife,
Which when he spyde vpon the earth t'encroch,
For some like Snailes, some did like spyders shew,
Ouer the dore thus written she did spye
Whom such when as Malbecco spyed clere,
A Lyon spyes fast running towards him,
And whilest he bath'd, with her two crafty spyes,
Nor brasen walls, nor many wakefull spyes,
Of their franke loues, free from all gealous spyes:
And closely tempted with their craftie spyes;
But he them spying, gan to turne aside,
But they him spying, both with greedy forse
When she at last him spying thus bespake;
Him spying, with fresh onset he assaild,
Him Atin spying, knew right well of yore,
And their bright Squadrons round about vs plant,
This squalid weede, the patterne of dispaire,
Most squalid garments, fit for such a day,
The litle babe did loudly scrike and squall,
When as they saw a Squire in squallid weed,
But kicks, and squals, and shriekes for fell despight:
And catching vp in hast his three square shield,
Had riuen many a brest with pikehead square;
Into great Ingoes, and to wedges square;
Me seemes the world is runne quite out of square,
A stately Pallace built of squared bricke,
Where many Groomes and Squiers readie were,
And squiers make hast to helpe their Lords fordonne.
With squinted eyes contrarie wayes intended,
Like a young Squire, in loues and lusty-hed
Together with his Squire, arayed meet:
A gentle youth, his dearely loued Squire
So with the Squire, th'admirer of his might,
Then tooke that Squire an horne of bugle small,
But him the Squire made quickly to retrate,
To see his loued Squire into such thraldome brought.
The light-foot Squire her quickly turnd around,
Forthwith he gaue in charge vnto his Squire,
There fairely them receiues a gentle Squire,
As might become a Squire so great persons to greet.
To seeke that knight, where him that craftie Squire
Till her that Squire bespake, Madame my liefe,
When she her Squire heard speake, she gan appease
Eftsoone she said, Ah gentle trustie Squire,
To be her Squire, and do her seruice well aguisd.
But temperance (said he) with golden squire
Turning about he saw that wretched Squire,
It was a faithlesse Squire, that was the sourse
Said Guyon, Squire, sore haue ye beene diseasd;
Wrath, gelosie, griefe, loue this Squire haue layd thus low.
Vnlucky Squire (said Guyon) sith thou hast
Whose squire bore after him an heben launce,
Till that the Squire gan nigher to approch;
With his gay Squire issuing did espy,
Had not his gentle Squire beheld his paine,
The Squire arriuing, fiercely in his armes
Tho comming to his Squire, that kept his steed,
But his good Squire him helping vp with speed,
And him beside an aged Squire there rode,
And euery knight, and euery gentle Squire
And as her Squire attend her carefully:
Bad her old Squire vnlace her lofty creast;
But Timias, the Princes gentle Squire,
The want of his good Squire late left behind,
And bold, as euer Squire that waited by knights side.
Had vsed bene of that foolehardy Squire;
By that same way they knew that Squire vnknowne
The gentle Squire came ryding that same way,
That stroke the hardy Squire did sore displease,
They three be dead with shame, the Squire liues with renowne.
Now God thee keepe, thou gentlest Squire aliue,
Shortly she came, whereas that woefull Squire
Thereat she blushing said, Ah gentle Squire,
Thither they brought that wounded Squire, and layd
Thou a meane Squire, of meeke and lowly place,
Satyrane saues the Squire of Dames
She bore before her lap a dolefull Squire,
At length he spide, whereas that wofull Squire,
Then trembling yet through feare, the Squire bespake,
Ah gentle Squire (quoth he) tell at one word,
Perdy, (said Satyrane) thou Squire of Dames,
Who hauing ended with that Squire of Dames
Ye noble knights (said then the Squire of Dames)
Thereat displeasd they were, till that young Squire
Into that Castle (as that Squire does tell.)
Till that young Squire him reared from below;
From whom the Squire of Dames was reft whylere;
With her owne trusty Squire, both full of feare,
And therefore gan aduize with her old Squire,
False traitour squire, false squire, of falsest knight,
False traitour squire, false squire, of falsest knight,
Yet thou false Squire his fault shalt deare aby,
Had not a Squire, euen he the Squire of Dames,
Had not a Squire, euen he the Squire of Dames,
Fond Squire, full angry then sayd Paridell,
A read thou Squire, that I the man may learne,
They sent that Squire afore, to vnderstand,
Sent forth their Squire to haue them both descride,
Which when that scornefull Squire of Dames did vew,
And that old aged Dame, his faithfull Squire,
And with him eke that aged Squire attone;
The Squire her loues, and being blam'd
Yet was he but a Squire of low degree;
I with that Squire agreede away to flit,
And that same gentle Squire arriu'd in place,
Which drery sight the gentle Squire espying,
For euer when the Squire his iauelin shooke,
That scarse the Squire his hand could once vpreare,
She left the gentle Squire with Amoret:
That albeit his owne deare Squire he were,
The gentle Squire recouers grace,
Which to this gentle Squire did happen late.
Her gentle Squire through her displeasure did pertake.
With which the Squire in her defence her sore astound.
A Squire came gallopping, as he would flie;
He all the way did rage at that same Squire,
Came to that Squire, yet trembling euery vaine:
Therewith both Squire and dwarfe did tomble downe
Which when that Squire beheld, he woxe full glad
All which was thus to him declared by that Squire.
So as it fell there was a gentle Squire,
This louely swaine the Squire of low degree;
And told his Dame, her Squire of low degree
For me he did mistake that Squire to be;
The Squire of low degree releast
Yet did this trustie Squire with proud disdaine
Then did he take that chaced Squire, and layd
But saw him sencelesse by the Squire vpstaide,
And that same Squire of treason to vpbraide.
Amongst the rest, that Squire of low degree
Which was the captiue Squire she lou'd so deare,
That trusty Squire he wisely well did moue
When as they saw a Squire in squallid weed,
By that same carefull Squire did then abide,
That did betwixt him and that Squire betide.
Well did the Squire perceiue him selfe too weake,
But that same Squire, to whom she was more dere,
Not so thou Squire, (he sayd) but thine I deeme
Much did that Squire Sir Artegall adore,
And as his Squire him offred euermore
When as by chaunce a comely Squire he found,
Vnhappy Squire, what hard mishap thee brought
Sayd then that Squire: The Lady which doth owne
Eftsoones he loosd that Squire, and so him left,
But gaue them streight vnto that Squire againe,
He makes him Squire, and of him learnes
That ye will make me Squire without delay,
So he him dubbed, and his Squire did call.
Glad would I surely be, thou courteous Squire,
Lo where a knight together with his squire,
For well they wist, that Squire to be so bold,
So did that Squire his foes disperse, and driue asonder.
With noise whereof the Squire now nigh aghast,
To be his Timias, his owne true Squire,
To whom the Squire nought aunswered againe,
Which when that Squire beheld, he to them stept,
And eke this Squire, who likewise wounded was
Ne yet that gentle Squire, for grieuous paine
Vnto their iourney; but that Squire and Dame
The Hermite heales both Squire and dame
Made in the bodies of that Squire and Dame;
The Squire, for that he courteous was indeed,
In th'harts of many a knight, and many a gentle squire.
When as the gentle Squire, with faire Serene,
Whose cruell handling when that Squire beheld,
So did the Squire, the whiles the Carle did fret,
Who after thraldome of the gentle Squire,
The Squire him selfe when as he saw his Lord,
Yond Lady and her Squire with foule despight
See how they doe that Squire beat and reuile;
It was his owne true groome, the gentle Squire,
When first the gentle Squire at variaunce fell
He fine would dight; sometimes the squirell wild
Of Squires and Ladies equipaged well,
And all was full of Damzels, and of Squires,
In which these Squires true friendship more did sway,
Of Knights and Squires to him vnknowne afore:
So did the other knights and Squires, which him did see.
He chaunst to come, whereas two comely Squires,
Seem'd that for it these Squires at ods did fall,
And all about the fields like Squirrels hunt;
Or wanton squirrels, in the woods farre sought,
Call me the Squyre of Dames that me beseemeth well.
But read, thou Squyre of Dames, what vow is this,
With that same Squyre, returned backe againe
Who her together with his Squyre
And in some stable neare did set him vp to feede.
And stablish termes betwixt both their requests,
Of that vilde race, and stablished my peace.
For stint of strife, and stablishment of rest
And aged limbs on Cypresse stadle stout,
And in his hand a Iacobs staffe, to stay
That on a staffe his feeble steps did frame,
Wont on a staffe his feeble steps to stay,
That with a staffe his feeble steps did stire,
And with his steedie staffe did point his way:
But on a staffe her feeble steps did stay;
Sometimes her staffe, though it her one leg were,
Which with a staffe, all full of litle snags
Tho lifting vp his vertuous staffe on hye,
The Palmer ouer them his staffe vpheld,
His mighty staffe, that could all charmes defeat:
Such wondrous powre did in that staffe appeare,
Such vertue in his staffe had eke this Palmer sage.
Holding a staffe in hand for more formalitee.
And broke his staffe, with which he charmed semblants sly.
Streight way he with his vertuous staffe them strooke,
And with his staffe, that driues his Heard astray,
It forth to wrest, the staffe a sunder brake,
And in his hand an huge long staffe he held,
Now like a Stag, now like a faulcon flit:
The Parthian strikes a stag with shiuering dart,
Of th'honorable stage of womanhead,
Yclad in costly garments, fit for tragicke Stage.
Fayre Canacee vpon a stately stage
Therein were diuerse roomes, and diuerse stages,
Their steeds do stagger, and amazed stand,
But made him stagger, as he were not well:
Her Steed did stagger with that puissaunt strooke;
At puffe of euery storme doth stagger here and theare.
It made her stagger oft, and stare with ghastly eye.
That makes the wals to stagger with astonishment:
That made him stagger with vncertaine sway,
That made him stagger, and stand halfe agast
That oft he made him stagger as vnstayd,
He staggered to and fro in doubtfull sted.
